title: 113_hr3131
content: The Act titled "National Park Service Study Act of 2013" includes provisions for special resource studies. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct special resource studies on various sites including the Kau coast in Hawaii, prehistoric sites in the Northern Mariana Islands, Aleut villages in Alaska, Japanese American relocation centers in multiple states, Mahaulepu in Kauai, Goldfield mining sites in Nevada, and the Hudson River Valley in New York. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct special resource studies on various sites including Goldfield mining sites in Nevada, the Hudson River Valley in New York, Norman Studios in Florida, Mobile-Tensaw River Delta in Alabama, Galveston Bay in Texas, Pullman site in Illinois, northern coast of Maui in Hawaii, and historic sites on Midway Atoll. The studies will evaluate national significance, suitability for National Park System designation, and preservation alternatives by governmental or private entities. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct special resource studies on various sites to evaluate national significance, suitability for National Park System designation, and preservation alternatives. The studies will involve consultation with governmental and private entities, cost estimates for associated activities, and compliance with applicable laws. SEC. 3. SPECIAL RESOURCE STUDY UPDATES. The Secretary of the Interior will update studies on World War II Sites in Palau and Vermejo Ranch in New Mexico/Colorado. The update will determine if the sites should be designated as part of the National Park System, explore preservation alternatives, consult with relevant entities, and provide cost estimates for federal involvement. The Secretary of the Interior will update studies on World War II Sites in Palau and Vermejo Ranch in New Mexico/Colorado to determine their designation as part of the National Park System, explore preservation alternatives, consult with relevant entities, and provide cost estimates for federal involvement. SEC. 4. BUFFALO SOLDIERS IN THE NATIONAL PARKS STUDY. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study on commemorating the Buffalo Soldiers' role in early national parks. This includes assessing their history, considering a historic trail from San Francisco to national parks, identifying properties for historic designation, and enhancing public awareness of their stewardship. The study will focus on the Buffalo Soldiers' stewardship role in national parks and their connection to African-American military service after the Civil War. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study to identify significant sites in the Southern United States related to the Reconstruction era. Recommendations will be made for commemorating and interpreting these sites, including new national historic landmarks and potential inclusion in the National Park System. Additionally, there will be a study on the boundary expansion of the Chattahoochee River. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study to determine the suitability and feasibility of expanding the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area by approximately 45 miles. The study will analyze resources, operational issues, protection of critical resources, feasibility of administration, and alternative management options. The study will assess the expansion of the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area by 45 miles, considering resources, operational issues, protection of critical resources, feasibility of administration, and alternative management options. Factors such as configuration, ownership, costs, and adequacy of alternatives will be evaluated. The Secretary of the Interior must submit a report to the House Committee on Natural Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources within 3 years of funds being allocated for each study under the Act. The report should include the results of the study, along with any conclusions and recommendations made by the Secretary based on those results.
